Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Automatically Generating Contextually-Relevant Visualizations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Information visualizations, such as charts and maps, can greatly enhance news articles by adding context, helping the reader understand complex facts, aiding in decision making, and making information more memorable. Unfortunately, creating good news visualizations is a difficult and labor-intensive task that involves numerous complex decisions. A designer must identify data relevant to the article, clean the data, generate the visualization (a complex process on its own), and provide annotations to connect the article and visualization. While some design guidelines have been developed, many decisions are based on designer intuition, a process that is not scalable to the thousands of news articles that are published every day. This project seeks to build intelligent tools to help designers more quickly create good news visualizations and to develop systems that generate news visualizations autonomously. This research project will enhance citizen understanding of complex information in the news and improve numerical, graphical, and geography literacy. Additionally, the research will provide support for new job categories (e.g., data scientists, computational journalists, data analysts, etc.) and existing companies (e.g., online media, search engines, etc.) in their evolution to new interactive platforms. The research results will be integrated into a broad set of widely accessible educational materials for a variety of courses (visualization, spatial computing, and text analysis) and will serve as research and practical training for undergraduates, graduates, and professionals.

Providing a scalable solution to automatically generating contextually-relevant visualizations requires the understanding and encoding of the design process. Specifically, the goals of this project are (a) identifying the decision process of visualization designers, (b) creating automated components that operationalize these decisions including text processing, searching through a wide range of heterogeneous data sources and datasets (e.g. census data, stock market data, government macroeconomic data), and automatic visualization construction and annotation, and (c) ranking of the visualizations based on well-known quantitative metrics from information retrieval and information visualization such as relevance, expressiveness, and effectiveness. By extracting key comparisons from an article's text through the use of natural language processing and using existing visualization-article pairs as an evaluation corpus, the system will ensure that relevant datasets are found and that the selected visual forms preserve and enhance the information conveyed in the article. For example, the system will automatically create thematic maps for geospatial comparisons of population change in the U.S. and time series for longitudinal comparisons of company financial results. Although the focus of this work in on the news domain, the research can be extended to other application areas including textbooks, internal company reports, and more generally, to any texts that implicitly or explicitly correspond to quantitative data. Further information, including source code, demos, papers, and datasets, are available at the project homepage (http://txt2vis.cond.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Incorporating information visualizations—anything from charts to maps—in news articles can greatly serve the reader. Many articles contain extensive numerical facts and context that are hard to understand directly through text. Communicative visualizations can enhance these articles, aiding the reader in interpreting the information, understanding uncertainty, and ultimately making better decisions. News providers benefit from incorporating visualizations as they increase reader engagement.  Unfortunately, constructing good communicative visualizations is a difficult and costly task. We have built a number of systems that can produce visualizations for news articles with little, or no, journalist intervention. Our goal is to automatically “understand” the context of the article and produce appropriate visualizations. 


The research presented a number of specific challenges.  First, we want generated visualizations to be “relevant”. Second, we ideally want the visualizations to be “interesting” (e.g., they should show patterns instead of noise or be personally relevant and engaging). Third, we want the visualizations to be “expressive”—if a particular “fact” is discussed in the article (e.g., that the stock price was $20.40 in May of ’17), we want the fact to also appear in the visualization. Finally, we want the visualizations to be “effective”—they should be the best visualizations (bar chart, map, pie chart, scatter plot, time series, etc.) for the particular kind of data and objective.


To support these high-level objectives we pursued the problem in different ways which led us to build a number of algorithms, systems, and even design criteria for future deployment. One example is the VizByWiki system, an end-to-end solution that takes advantage of the millions of images on the Wikipedia Commons to enhance news articles. The system determines what the news article is talking about by finding related Wikipedia articles based on the text of the article. From there, we determine good images (largely visualizations) that are related to the topic. 


A particular lesson learned from the research was that there is significant interest from journalists in playing an active role in generating visualizations. To better support them, we built DataTone, a natural-language-driven data visualization framework. The system could understand commands like “show me gold medal winners by country for the last summer Olympics.” DataTone could automatically generate an appropriate visualization. A particular innovation of this work that is broadly applicable is in managing the “noise” and “uncertainty” when we use AI systems. Because the AI components are not always clear about what the end-user wants (due to limited training data, or the inherent ambiguity of human language), they can make mistakes in producing an answer. In our case, we can make mistakes in parsing the original query, in mapping the request to columns in the database system, and in picking the right visualization format. Even if the end-user can figure out where the problem was (which they usually can’t) it is difficult to correct. DataTone explicitly captured the space of options the AI systems produced, instead of only the best guess, and through innovative user interface techniques allowed the end-user to fix the errors and get the visualizations they wanted.


Visualizations should not only be relevant and effective, but they should also be interesting and engaging. Given many possible visualizations, a key challenge in our research was finding which one to show. That is, which visualization will be most interesting. One thing that we determined was that visualizations that had very clear patterns were viewed as more interesting than those that looked like noise. For example, a map with auto-spatial correlation (e.g., the east coast was noticeably different than the west coast, or one county was very different than its neighbors) was viewed as more interesting. A second key result of our work was that visualizations that were personalized (e.g., compared the local unemployment levels to the state or national ones) were often more engaging. This technique of personalizing is being adopted by news organizations. We built a specific system, called Persalog, that allows journalists to write articles where both text and visualizations are personalized based on the reader. In addition to making this system easy to use, we worked with journalists to generate a set of guidelines about when it was appropriate to use these kinds of personalization.


Finally, as part of our education mission, we devised ways of training students to create better visualizations. While some use new systems such as DataTone, some like VisItCards are extremely lo-fi. VisItCards is a card-game for use in a design workshop that forces teams of visualization designers to produce different alternatives for visualizations and to understand the trade-offs in different designs.
